summary: A grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Square, Inc. (now Block, Inc.) demanding financial records related to a specific phone number, as part of an investigation into alleged violations of federal conspiracy, false statements, and obstruction statutes. The subpoena seeks comprehensive account and payment information, indicating a financial investigation linked to the broader Epstein case.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Signed the grand jury subpoena as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, authorizing the demand for records from Square, Inc.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The AUSA is the point of contact for compliance with the subpoena and is responsible for receiving the requested records from Square, Inc. The name is redacted in the document.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance Date for Square, Inc.
events.description: The date by which Square, Inc. was commanded to appear before a grand jury in the Southern District of New York or produce the requested financial records.

events.title: Subpoena Issuance Date
events.description: The date the grand jury subpoena was issued and signed by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Manhattan, New York, NY
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (U.S. Attorney's Office)
1455 Market Street, Suite 600, San Francisco, CA 94103 (Square, Inc. address)
keyFacts: The subpoena targets financial records from Square, Inc. (Cash App) associated with a specific, redacted phone number, indicating investigators were tracing financial transactions linked to an individual or entity in the Epstein investigation.

The investigation involves alleged violations of 18 U.S.C. §§ 371 (conspiracy), 1001 (false statements), and 1519 (destruction, alteration, or falsification of records in federal investigations), suggesting a focus on obstructive conduct and false statements.

The document demonstrates the use of a grand jury subpoena to obtain detailed digital financial records, including subscriber info, IP addresses, session logs, and payment details, highlighting the forensic financial aspect of the investigation.
The subpoena allows Square, Inc. to avoid a physical appearance by producing records with a custodian declaration, which is a standard procedure for obtaining business records in lieu of testimony.
